author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Shogun’ and ‘The Regime’
description: FX premieres a new show set in Japan in the 1600s. A new mini-series starring Kate Winslet airs on HBO.
content: For those like myself who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Feb. 26-March 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Reject Bipartisan Map and Will Redraw N.Y. House Districts
description: With the battle for House control likely to run through New York, Democrats in the State Legislature voted down a plan drawn by a bipartisan commission.
content: Democrats seized control over drawing New York’s congressional districts on Monday, rejecting a map proposed by the state’s bipartisan redistricting commission in favor of drafting new lines that could make key swing seats more Democratic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Joan Holden, 85, Playwright Who Skewered Rich and Powerful, Dies
description: As the principal writer for the Obie-winning San Francisco Mime Troupe, she created iconoclastic left-wing satire that courted both chuckles and outrage.
content: To Joan Holden, a fiercely left-wing playwright for the award-winning San Francisco Mime Troupe,  life in a capitalist society offered almost too many targets: conniving politicians, labor-squashing industrialists and masters of war looking to profit by spreading conflict around the globe, to name just a few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Republican Opposition to Birth Control Bill Could Alienate Voters, Poll Finds
description: A survey conducted by Americans for Contraception shows the overwhelming popularity of birth control, and suggests voters are primed to punish Republicans for opposing a measure to protect access to it.
content: One month after the Supreme Court struck down the right to an abortion, Democrats who then controlled the House pushed through a bill aimed to ensure access to contraception nationwide. All but eight Republicans opposed it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Kenneth Mitchell, Known for ‘Star Trek’ and ‘Captain Marvel’ Roles, Dies at 49
description: Mr. Mitchell, a Canadian actor who appeared on “Star Trek: Discovery,” had A.L.S.
content: Kenneth Mitchell, a Canadian actor known for his roles on the series “Star Trek: Discovery” and the film “Captain Marvel,” died on Saturday. He was 49.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Giving Big, a California Couple Gets Gratitude and Scrutiny
description: Lynda and Stewart Resnick have directed their pistachio fortune toward large, transformational gifts, but also drawn some criticism for their water use in an often parched state.
content: Standing on the grand staircase of Lynda and Stewart Resnick's opulent Beverly Hills mansion at a party last fall — where Diane Keaton, Bob Iger and Brian Grazer were among the luminaries making small talk over crudités and Sazerac cocktails — the author Walter Isaacson took a moment to thank his hosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noreen Malone
title: Is America All-Knowing and All-Powerful? Yes, Thought Saddam Hussein.
description: In “The Achilles Trap,” Steve Coll paints the demise of the Iraqi dictator as a tragedy of misperceptions on both sides.
content: People love to imagine that world affairs are a game of chess, played by judicious leaders trying to outwit each other, acting with perfect self-knowledge and a clear understanding of what their opponent might do. But consider Vladimir Putin, Benjamin Netanyahu or Yahya Sinwar. There can be a tragic mismatch between the interests of a nation and the self-interest of its leaders. The people running the show are people. They act on their whims, and with myopic agendas. They screw up. Call it the frail man theory of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: The Case That Could Change Social Media, and an Evacuation Plan for Parts of Gaza
description: Plus, Flaco the owl honored in N.Y.C.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Palestinian Authority’s Government Submits Resignation as U.S. Calls for Change
description: It was not clear whether the appointment of a new prime minister and cabinet would be enough to revamp the authority or persuade Israel to let it govern Gaza after the war there ends.
content: Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh of the Palestinian Authority, the body that administers part of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, tendered the resignation of his cabinet on Monday, according to the authority’s official news agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Happened When Saudi Arabia Took its Money and Influence to Miami
description: Dozens of U.S. financiers and investors attended the Future Investment Initiative to deepen their business ties with the kingdom.
content: America’s corporate elite were everywhere in Miami at the Future Investment Initiative conference, Saudi Arabia’s latest bid to showcase its extensive wealth and deepen ties with Western business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Your Inhalers and EpiPens Aren’t Very Healthy for the Environment
description: For eco-conscious consumers of personal medical devices, recycling options are limited. Some companies are trying to change that.
content: Single-use insulin pens changed Brian Brandell’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Another Winter at the Front Lines in Ukraine
description: On frozen roads with frozen pens, a reporter navigates bunkers and interviews weary soldiers.
content: Reporting on the war in Ukraine often feels like one long camping expedition. You bundle up in warm layers and set off in the dark to get into place — embedded with a military unit, for example, somewhere along the 600-mile front line — before sunrise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Hungary’s Parliament Approves Sweden’s NATO Bid After Stalling
description: Budapest had been the final obstacle to the Nordic country’s joining the alliance, which has been trying to isolate Russia over its war in Ukraine.
content: Hungary’s Parliament voted on Monday to accept Sweden as a new member of NATO, sealing a major shift in the balance of power between the West and Russia set off by war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Roni Stoneman, Country Music’s ‘First Lady of the Banjo,’ Dies at 85
description: A featured player on ‘Hee Haw’ and member of the famed Stoneman Family, she was the first woman to play modern bluegrass banjo on a phonograph record.
content: Roni Stoneman, a virtuoso banjo player, mainstay of the country music television show “Hee Haw” and one of the last surviving members of the Stoneman Family, a renowned Appalachian string band, died on Thursday at her home in Murfreesboro, Tenn. She was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Keenan and Rick Rojas
title: ‘Cop City’ Prosecutions Hinge on a New Definition of Domestic Terrorism
description: Are the protesters against a new police training center part of a violent “extremist organization,” or are the serious charges they face a means of stifling free speech?
content: In a forest on the outskirts of Atlanta last March, hundreds of protesters had gathered once again to try to stop the construction of a new police and fire training center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Americans’ Savings Are Shrinking. Should We Be Worried?
description: Despite the decline, American consumers still have money to spend.
content: If there is a recession in the United States this year, it probably won’t be because consumers spontaneously run out of spending power. (If unemployment abruptly rises, that’s another matter.) I’ve put together five charts that show that consumers are in reasonably good shape, although life is getting harder for the most vulnerable groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Senate Aide Investigated Over Unofficial Actions in Ukraine
description: Kyle Parker says he delivered sniper gear as part of his unabashed support for Ukraine. Investigators say there may be “counterintelligence issues.”
content: A senior Capitol Hill staff member who is a longtime voice on Russia policy is under congressional investigation over his frequent trips to Ukraine’s war zones and providing what he said was $30,000 in sniper gear to its military, documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Wegman
title: The Crisis in Teaching Constitutional Law
description: A highly politicized Supreme Court makes it far more difficult to teach students about the fundamentals of the American legal system.
content: If you attended law school at any time over the past half-century, your course in constitutional law likely followed a well-worn path.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 26, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 26, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: In Calling Out Tucker Carlson, Jon Stewart Reminds Us He Has (Old-Fashioned) Skills
description: The comedian has always had a sharp Borscht Belt approach, but only in his return to “The Daily Show” can we see how he wields this style so expertly.
content: When it was announced that Jon Stewart was returning to “The Daily Show” every Monday, there was some understandable skepticism. His track record since leaving the program in 2015 has been spotty at best, including an HBO project that never aired and another on Apple TV+ that didn’t gain traction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Oppenheimer’ Wins Producers Guild Award. Is the Best-Picture Oscar Next?
description: With the victory, the Christopher Nolan biopic has swept the guild prizes, a strong predictor of its chances at the Academy Awards.
content: There’s simply no stopping “Oppenheimer.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Canadian Skaters Demand Bronze Medals in Olympics Dispute
description: Reviving a fight from the 2022 Games, Canada’s team said skating officials improperly awarded third place to Russia. The Russians filed three cases, asking for the gold.
content: Nearly a month after international figure skating’s governing body revised the results of a marquee competition at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, stripping Russia of the gold medal and giving the United States team a long-delayed victory, a new fight about the outcome erupted on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: A Watch With an Irresistible Tick
description: This new numbered-edition Omega Speedmaster sounds as good as it looks.
content: Time ticks by silently but, in the arcane universe of mechanical watches, sound is the ultimate achievement. While chiming clocks were pioneered in the 1600s, it wasn’t until the late 19th century that the apparatus was perfected in miniature. Squeezing in the more than 100 additional components necessary to have a modern-style wristwatch strike with pinpoint accuracy and rich, clear peals — each watch sounds subtly different — is considered the height of horological craft, and most companies abandoned such complex models long ago. But a few holdouts continue to make such timepieces. Among them is Omega, whose new numbered-edition Speedmaster marries the Swiss brand’s stopwatch chronograph feature with a minute repeater, enabling wearers to press a button that triggers a series of tones to signal the minutes, tens of seconds and seconds. The unique combination, housed in an 18-karat gold case with an aventurine dial and rose guilloche subdials, is arrestingly beautiful while ringing every bell. Omega Speedmaster Chrono Chime, price on request, omegawatches.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Crosbie
title: At CPAC, Steve Bannon Hosted the Only Party That Mattered
description: A Saturday night bash hosted by Mr. Bannon was the main social event in an otherwise subdued weekend at the conservative convention.
content: On Saturday night, Stephen K. Bannon grabbed the microphone on the upper level of Tom’s Watch Bar, a sports bar in National Harbor, Md., to close out the final after-party of the 2024 Conservative Political Action Conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Spending Impasse Persists Amid G.O.P. Resistance as Partial Shutdown Looms
description: With Republicans insisting on adding right-wing policy measures to spending bills, lawmakers are running out of time to strike a deal to avert a partial government shutdown before a deadline of Friday at midnight.
content: Congressional leaders have failed to reach a deal on legislation to keep federal funding going past Friday, with Republicans insisting on adding right-wing policy dictates to the spending bills, pushing the government to the brink of a partial shutdown within days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Takeaways From the Supreme Court Arguments on Social Media Laws
description: Laws in Texas and Florida seek to limit social media companies’ ability to moderate content on their platforms and could shape the future of speech on the internet.
content: The Supreme Court heard arguments for nearly four hours on Monday on a pair of First Amendment cases challenging laws in Florida and Texas that seek to limit the ability of internet companies to moderate content on their platforms. Here are some takeaways:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Where Is Wendy Williams?’: 5 Takeaways From the Documentary
description: The Lifetime series gave an inside look at the television star’s life and struggles since she last hosted her talk show in 2021.
content: Since 2021, daytime television viewers and pop culture fanatics alike have been wondering, where is Wendy Williams?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Paul L. Gioia, Who Oversaw Nuclear Power in New York, Dies at 81
description: As head of the state’s Public Service Commission, he clashed with Gov. Mario Cuomo over the management of two troubled power plants and was ousted by him.
content: Paul L. Gioia, a former apprentice electrician who for five years oversaw New York State’s utility companies as they struggled to cope with the public’s growing concerns over nuclear power plants and consumer complaints about their costs, died on Feb. 13 at his home in Loudonville, N.Y. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: NASA’s Crash Into an Asteroid May Have Altered Its Shape
description: A new study using simulations suggests the impact in 2022 transformed the space rock into an M&M-like flat-top oval.
content: In 2022, when NASA’s $325 million spacecraft crashed into an asteroid named Dimorphos at 14,000 miles per hour, cheers and applause erupted back on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Biden’s Next Steps on Immigration
description: The president has come to recognize that the surge of undocumented immigration is a threat to his re-election.
content: President Biden has come to recognize that the surge of undocumented immigration during his presidency is a threat to his re-election. He knows that most voters are unhappy about the increase. So are mayors and governors who have been left to deal with an expensive and often chaotic situation — such as in Denver, the subject of a recent Times story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Your 2024 Guide to Covid Symptoms and Treatment
description: Rest, fluids and medications are your friends.
content: We’re four years into the pandemic, and by this point, most Americans have had Covid at least once. But when the virus comes for us (again), it can still feel just as alarming as your first bout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: Months After Backing Haley, Koch Network Suspends Support for Her Campaign
description: The group’s chief executive wrote in an email to staff on Sunday that it would now focus on House and Senate races.
content: The political network created by the billionaire industrialist Koch brothers announced on Sunday that it was suspending its support for Nikki Haley in the presidential primary after her latest defeat in South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Chris Gauthier, ‘Once Upon a Time’ and ‘Eureka’ Actor, Dies at 48
description: Mr. Gauthier appeared in dozens of television shows and films, including “Freddy vs. Jason” and “Watchmen.”
content: Chris Gauthier, a prolific British-born, Canadian actor known for his roles in the television shows “Once Upon a Time” and “Eureka,” died on Friday. He was 48.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Escoffery
title: Tommy Orange’s ‘There There’ Sequel Is a Towering Achievement
description: “Wandering Stars” considers the fallout of colonization and the forced assimilation of Native Americans.
content: Tommy Orange triumphantly returns with “Wandering Stars,” the follow-up to his groundbreaking 2018 debut, “There There.” Part prequel, part sequel, yet wholly standing on its own, Orange’s novel follows the descendants of Jude Star, a Cheyenne survivor of the 1864 Sand Creek massacre, for more than a century and a half, before catching up with the present day and landing in the aftermath of the first book’s harrowing climax.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Longtime Disney Movie Executive Sean Bailey Steps Down
description: He had hits with live-action versions of “Aladdin” and “The Lion King,” but Disney has been on a box office cold streak more recently.
content: Sean Bailey, the longtime president of Walt Disney Studios Motion Picture Production, resigned Monday amid a leadership shuffling at Disney’s film division, which has been under attack by some investors for disappointing results at the box office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Rally in Michigan Urges Protest Vote Against Biden’s Israel Policies
description: With the state’s primary on Tuesday, speakers at a gathering in Dearborn, Mich., pushed voters to cast a ballot for “uncommitted” in objection to President Biden’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war.
content: Two days before the Michigan Democratic primary, speakers at a rally on Sunday in Dearborn, Mich., urged voters to withhold their support from President Biden over his policy on the war in Gaza — and said that only Mr. Biden and Democrats who support his Israel policies would be to blame if the protest vote helped former President Donald J. Trump win in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: F.T.C. Sues to Block Kroger-Albertsons Grocery Store Deal
description: The regulator is trying to stop the largest supermarket merger in history, arguing that the deal would eliminate competition and raise prices for consumers.
content: The Federal Trade Commission and several state attorneys general on Monday sued to block Kroger, the supermarket giant, from completing its $24.6 billion acquisition of the grocery chain Albertsons, saying the deal would hurt competition in the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie J. M. Baker
title: They Promoted Body Positivity. Then They Lost Weight.
description: Do plus-size influencers owe their followers an explanation when their bodies change?
content: Tianna James used to love looking at the photographs Dronme Davis posted of herself on Instagram. Ms. Davis, a plus-size model, included pictures from her modeling campaigns alongside selfies of her stretch-marked stomach with captions like “fat belly saggy tits Sunday.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller and Isabel Kershner
title: Israeli Forces Will Move Into Rafah, Cease-Fire Deal or Not, Netanyahu Says
description: Amid signs of progress toward a pause in the fighting, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Israeli forces planned to keep pushing into Gaza.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday that Israeli forces would push into the southern Gaza Strip city of Rafah regardless of the outcome of talks to pause the fighting that appear to have been making some progress in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon
title: Arrest of Migrant in Georgia Killing Turns City Into Latest Battleground on Immigration
description: A personal and community tragedy got caught up in the national politics of immigration after a migrant from Venezuela was charged in the death of a former University of Georgia student.
content: When a 22-year-old nursing student was found dead on a wooded trail at the University of Georgia in what’s believed to be the first homicide on campus in nearly 30 years, it set off waves of grief and fear that shook the university to its core.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Florida Man Is In on the Joke, and Ready to Make a Game of It
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 26, 2024.
content: “We understand that Florida is weird. We embrace it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: An Abrupt Temperature Change Could Bring Hail and Tornadoes to the Midwest
description: Cold air will sweep through the Central U.S. after days of unseasonable warmth, which could allow for severe storms to strike from Missouri to Michigan.
content: “Record-shattering warmth” followed immediately by frigidly cold weather will create the opportunity for hail the size of hen eggs and possible tornadoes in the Midwest on Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Chicago, St. Louis and Indianapolis all have some risk of severe storms, and residents there are also expected to experience an abrupt return to wearing multiple layers after days of short-sleeves weather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Alcorn
title: Can Your Personal Medical Devices Be Recycled?
description: Inhalers, EpiPens, home tests for flu or Covid, mouth guards. They accumulate in our homes, and recycling methods and advice can be tricky to pin down.
content: Most of the plastic in your medicine cabinet is high-quality, medical grade — and devilishly difficult to safely dispose of, let alone recycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: The Perfect Game Night Doesn’t Have to Be a Puzzle
description: No matter what game you’re playing, here are tips for a successful evening.
content: There’s something exhilarating about a great game night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Amy Schumer Says She Has Cushing’s Syndrome, a Hormonal Disorder
description: The comedian’s announcement came after she was targeted on social media for a change in her physical appearance during on-camera interviews this month.
content: The comedian Amy Schumer has announced that she has been diagnosed with a rare hormonal disorder called Cushing’s syndrome, after she was swarmed with comments on social media about a change in her physical appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simran Hans
title: In ‘The Regime,’ Kate Winslet Gets to Have a Little Fun
description: In the absurdist HBO limited series, she plays a central European dictator making it up as she goes along.
content: Chancellor Elena Vernham would like you to know she is “very much not ridiculous.” She would never serve salmon at an official event. (That would be “meek.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Premier League Cuts Everton’s Points Penalty, Easing Relegation Fears
description: The decision means the club will lose six points in the standings, not 10, potentially helping it to stay in the division and to remain financially viable.
content: Everton, a storied English soccer club trying to weather a serious financial storm, secured a modest victory on Monday when a record penalty that had sent it to the bottom of the Premier League standings was reduced on appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A New Voice in Fiction With a Mean Left Hook
description: Rita Bullwinkel’s debut novel, “Headshot,” spotlights eight boxers in a national tournament and the struggles of their inner lives.
content: It takes focus and discipline and a certain single-mindedness to become a good prize fighter. It takes those same qualities to write a book as fresh and strong and sinuous as “Headshot,” Rita Bullwinkel’s first novel, which is set in the world of young women’s boxing. To put this another way: Make room, American fiction, for a meaningful new voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Kayla Guo
title: Jeffries Weighs How to Force Ukraine Aid Vote While Keeping Democrats United
description: The House Democratic leader is facing a critical test of whether he can hold his party together long enough to force a vote on an aid package for Ukraine amid progressive opposition to its funding for Israel.
content: The stalemate on Capitol Hill over sending vital military aid to Ukraine is posing a critical test for Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the New York Democrat and minority leader, who may hold the only remaining key to overcoming Republican opposition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Azeen Ghorayshi, Eric Krupke, Alex Stern, Sydney Harper, Mary Wilson, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Alabama Ruling That Could Stop Families From Having Kids
description: The Alabama Supreme Court ruled this month that frozen embryos are children.
content: A surprise ruling from the Alabama Supreme Court has halted fertility treatments across the state and sent a shock wave through the world of reproductive health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Where to Learn More About Black History in California
description: The state has invested $15 million to improve research and public education on Black history at more than two dozen California state park sites.
content: In a cemetery on a back country road near Sacramento, three rows of granite gravestones bear the same inscription: “Unknown, moved from Negro Hill Cemetery by the U.S. Government — 1954.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should the Voting Age Be Lowered to 16?
description: New Jersey’s largest city will allow 16- and 17-year-olds to vote in school board elections. Would expanding voting rights empower young people and improve our political system?
content: How important is the right to vote — for democracy and for you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The NATO Welcoming Sweden Is Larger and More Determined
description: The alliance’s expansion, with Finland last year and soon Sweden, was a consequence from the invasion of Ukraine that Russia’s president may not have calculated.
content: BERLIN — Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine two years ago was an enormous shock to Europeans. Used to 30 years of post-Cold War peace, they had imagined European security would be built alongside a more democratic Russia, not reconstructed against a revisionist imperial war machine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: In Trump Criminal Case, Manhattan D.A. Asks for Gag Order Before Trial
description: Lawyers for Alvin L. Bragg, the district attorney, are seeking to protect jurors and witnesses in the first criminal prosecution of a former president.
content: Manhattan prosecutors on Monday asked the judge overseeing their criminal case against Donald J. Trump to prohibit the former president from attacking witnesses or exposing jurors’ identities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Pentagon Review Faults No One for Failure to Disclose Austin’s Illness
description: The defense secretary is also set to appear before a House committee this week to explain why he did not immediately tell the White House about his hospitalization.
content: Few expected the Pentagon’s internal review of Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III’s failure to tell President Biden and other senior leaders that he was in the hospital to amount to much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Says He’s Hopeful for a Gaza Cease-Fire Within a Week
description: The president offered a positive assessment of negotiations aimed at halting Israel’s military operations in exchange for the release of hostages held by Hamas.
content: President Biden said on Monday that he believed negotiators were nearing an agreement that would halt Israel’s military operations in Gaza within a week in exchange for the release of at least some of the more than 100 hostages being held by Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: ‘I Said, ‘What’s Your Plan About Marriage and Dating?’ And There Was Silence.’
description: Conservative-leaning intellectuals want more people to get married. But how does that actually happen? Jane Coaston interviews Brad Wilcox.
content: As of 2021, around 25 percent of 40-year-old Americans are not married — the highest percentage ever recorded. While divorce rates have plummeted from their early 1980s high, fewer people are choosing to marry in the first place. Why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Odysseus Sends Moon Landing Photos Home With Time Running Out
description: The privately built American spacecraft’s ability to send home images and other data has been limited by its sideways landing. On another part of the moon, a Japanese spacecraft woke up.
content: Odysseus, the American robotic spacecraft that landed on the moon last week, is likely to die in the next day or so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Chipmakers Seek More Than $70 Billion in Federal Subsidies
description: Gina Raimondo, the commerce secretary, said new investments would put the U.S. on track to produce roughly 20% of the world’s most advanced logic chips by the end of the decade.
content: Companies that produce the most advanced semiconductors have requested more than $70 billion in federal subsidies, roughly twice the amount of funding that is available, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M.H. Miller and Miranda Barnes
title: Against All Odds, New York’s Artist Buildings Have Survived
description: Generations of creatives once flocked to the city seeking affordable rent. Now, despite skyrocketing real estate prices, some continue to carve out studio spaces of their own.
content: New York’s reputation as a beacon for artists was never inevitable. Only after World War II had destabilized Europe was the city able to usurp Paris as the commercial center of the art business. Veterans returning from abroad found a new diversity of college art programs and art schools thanks to the abundance of federal education grants made available by the G.I. Bill. The expansion of government-subsidized housing loans meant that cheap space was also easy to come by, as New York had a then-ample stock of residential and industrial buildings. In the following decades, which saw the birth of Abstract Expressionism, followed by Pop Art, followed by minimalism — all locally grown movements — the city also became the capital of what we now call the art world, a multibillion-dollar, mostly unregulated global economy of galleries, auction houses and fairs that has grown without interruption through wars, recessions and two pandemics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Near Flaco’s Hunting Grounds, a Regreening of Central Park
description: Next to the North Woods, the Lasker Pool site is being renovated and integrated into the landscape, an architect on the project said.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a construction site in Central Park that is next to a favorite hunting ground of Flaco, the celebrity Eurasian eagle-owl who died last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Marlise Simons
title: Top U.N. Court Holds Last Day of Hearings on Israeli Occupation
description: The hearings on the legality of Israel’s occupation of Palestinian territories have put more pressure on Israel during the war in Gaza.
content: The United Nations’ top court on Monday heard a final day of arguments on the legality of Israel’s decades-long occupation of Palestinian territories, proceedings that have added pressure to Israel at a time when attention focuses on the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
title: Navalny Was Part of Discussions on a Prisoner Exchange
description: Allies of Aleksei Navalny said he was about to be freed in a swap. A Western official said discussions for his release and that of two Americans had been underway, but no deal was imminent.
content: Aides to Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who died this month, asserted on Monday that he had been on the verge of being freed in a prisoner exchange with the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Naked? With Strangers? In Europe, It’s How You Relax at the Spa.
description: Austria and Germany abound with popular resorts called thermen where getting the full sauna experience typically means having to take it all off.
content: Had I ever seen so much bare flesh in one room? Naked in a mixed-gender Austrian sauna, I sat opposite two dozen other nude people on wooden benches. Even after more than a year of living in Europe, as an American, I still felt a little uncomfortable sitting there in nothing but my own skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: A Conservative Judge’s Critique of the Supreme Court’s Reliance on Tradition
description: In remarks at Harvard, Judge Kevin C. Newsom said the justices had strayed from originalism in parts of their blockbuster opinions on abortion and guns.
content: Judges who are committed to originalism, which seeks to interpret the Constitution based on what it meant when it was adopted, often say they are guided by “text, history and tradition.” The phrase rolls nicely off the tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Prosecutors Reject Claims of Unfairness in Trump Classified Documents Case
description: Jack Smith, the special counsel, said in a court filing that never before had a former official “engaged in conduct remotely similar to Trump’s.”
content: Federal prosecutors on Monday rejected former President Donald J. Trump’s claims that he was unfairly charged with holding on to classified documents after he left office, saying that his case bore no comparison to the one in which President Biden was cleared of wrongdoing even though he was found in possession of classified materials after leaving the vice presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marissa Lorusso
title: Mannequin Pussy’s Music Is Built on Big Emotions (and Inside Jokes)
description: The band started as a cathartic outlet for the singer and guitarist Marisa Dabice, and grew into a tight-knit act that makes confrontational and tender punk.
content: “So, who’s the pig lover here?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: The Democratic Taboo
description: It’s airing concerns about President Biden’s campaign, or his age.
content: The Democratic Party has had no shortage of argument and dissent over the years. Internal battles and backbiting are part of what it means to be a modern-day Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Housing Costs Are Running Hot, but Is the Data Missing a Cooling Trend?
description: Pandemic disruptions may have muddled the measurement of home prices in inflation data. That could complicate the Fed’s course on interest rates.
content: The Federal Reserve may have a housing problem. At the very least, it has a housing riddle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
title: Macron Does Not Rule Out Sending Western Troops to Ukraine
description: The French leader said that talks had not resulted in any consensus among European officials on putting troops on the ground in an “official” way, but that “anything is possible.”
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France on Monday said “nothing should be ruled out” after he was asked about the possibility of sending Western troops to Ukraine in support of the embattled nation’s war against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: reluctant
description: This word has appeared in 993 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word reluctant has appeared in 993 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 29 in “He Stole Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers. He Thought They Had Real Rubies” by Michael Levenson:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing’s Safety Culture Faulted by F.A.A. in New Report
description: The report by a group of experts was commissioned at the behest of Congress and in response to fatal crashes involving 737 Max jets in 2018 and 2019.
content: Boeing’s safety culture remains flawed, despite improvements made after two fatal crashes involving the 737 Max 8 jet in 2018 and 2019, a Federal Aviation Administration report released on Monday found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Trump Media’s Impending Merger May Give Him a Financial Lifeline
description: The deadline for the former president to pay a $454 million civil fraud penalty coincides with the expected closing of a deal involving his social media platform, Truth Social.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s stake in Trump Media & Technology Group, his social media company, could be worth as much as $4 billion once a long-delayed merger closes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Ye Spends a Second Week at No. 1 With ‘Vultures 1’
description: The rapper once known as Kanye West’s collaborative album with Ty Dolla Sign repeats at the top of the Billboard 200, narrowly defeating an LP from Yeat.
content: Ye, the rapper and provocateur formerly known as Kanye West, has the No. 1 album for a second week with “Vultures 1,” narrowly beating out a new release from the Oregon rapper Yeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Eagles’ Don Henley Testifies That Lyrics Taken From Him Were Personal
description: Mr. Henley testified in a Manhattan courtroom, where three men are charged with conspiring to possess papers taken from a barn on his organic farm in Malibu.
content: Don Henley and Glenn Frey followed a routine while writing some of the most emblematic and enduring songs of the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: Ukraine said 31,000 of its soldiers had been killed.
content: Some 31,000 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed since Russia’s full-scale invasion began two years ago, Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said. It is the first time he has announced a concrete figure for Ukraine’s toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Targets a New Economic Villain: Shrinkflation
description: Liberals prodded the president for years to blame big corporations for price increases. He is finally doing so, in the grocery aisle.
content: On Super Bowl Sunday, the White House released a short video in which a smiling President Biden, sitting next to a table stocked with chips, cookies and sports drinks, slammed companies for reducing the package size and portions of popular foods without an accompanying reduction in price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Ronna McDaniel, the R.N.C.’s Top Official, Plans to Step Down on March 8
description: Donald Trump has publicly backed a new leader, Michael Whatley, to replace her, as the former president continues to tighten his grip on the Republican Party.
content: The chairwoman of the Republican National Committee said on Monday that she would step down in just over a week, as former President Donald J. Trump seeks to install a new handpicked leader for the national party ahead of the general election this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Of All the Wrenching Details of Nex Benedict’s Death, This One Broke My Heart
description: A grieving grandmother in Oklahoma shows us the way.
content: There’s much we don’t know about why Nex Benedict, a nonbinary teenager in Owasso, Okla., died a day after a fight in a high school bathroom. But there are some things we do know, and all of them add up to tragedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: Texas Is Right. The Tech Giants Need to Be Regulated.
description: If the Supreme Court sides with social media platforms in NetChoice v. Paxton, that will jeopardize our ability to control our own future.
content: On the average day, some 95 million pictures are posted on Instagram, along with 34 million videos on TikTok and hundreds of millions of tweets. Some go viral, most don’t. And some percentage — the numbers are unclear — are taken down for violating the content rules set by the platforms. Given the volume of posts and videos, it is no exaggeration to say that the rules for social media have become the most important speech regulations on the planet, policing what can and cannot be said online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Vibrant Vegetarian Soup That’s Barely Any Work
description: Hetty Lui McKinnon’s new lemony pearl barley soup is exactly what to cook when you don’t feel like cooking.
content: Lacking the Italian suavity of farro or the good-for-you cred of quinoa, barley might seem a little frumpy. Thank goodness for Hetty Lui McKinnon, who reminds us that barley’s velvety, nubby texture and gentle flavor pair wonderfully with a wide range of ingredients beyond the usual mushrooms and beef. In her new recipe for lemony pearl barley soup, she brings out barley’s lighter, brighter side with a broth that’s enlivened with citrus and loads of feathery dill. A dollop of yogurt (dairy or coconut) and some fresh spinach add creaminess and just enough vegetable matter to make this a meal. It’s the perfect dish to have bubbling on the stove as winter softens into spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Unopened Case of More Than 10,000 Hockey Cards Sells for $3.7 Million
description: The sealed case could include the highly prized Wayne Gretzky rookie card. Or not. The buyer may never find out.
content: A sealed case filled with unopened boxes of Canadian hockey trading cards sold for $3.72 million on Sunday after a father and son found them while cleaning the father’s house in Saskatchewan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: $1 Billion Donation Will Provide Free Tuition at a Bronx Medical School
description: Ruth Gottesman, a longtime professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, is making free tuition available to all students going forward.
content: The 93-year-old widow of a Wall Street financier has donated $1 billion to a Bronx medical school, the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, with instructions that the gift be used to cover tuition for all students going forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Lee Hoyang, Prolific K-Pop Producer and Songwriter, Dies at 40
description: Professionally known as Shinsadong Tiger, he created the upbeat, catchy and danceable musical style that defined K-pop in the early 2010s.
content: Lee Hoyang, a prolific producer and songwriter of South Korean pop music who was professionally known as Shinsadong Tiger and who helped create some of the biggest K-pop hits of the 2010s, died on Friday in Seoul. He was 40.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Catie Edmondson
title: Days Before Shutdown Deadline, Biden Summons Congressional Leaders for Talks
description: President Biden plans to discuss the urgency of legislation to keep federal funding going past midnight on Friday.
content: President Biden will convene the top four congressional leaders at the White House on Tuesday as lawmakers swiftly run out of time to strike a deal to avert another partial government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Shogun’ Review: Rediscovering Japan
description: The FX remake of the classic mini-series is classed up, retuned for contemporary sensibilities and still an epic soap opera.
content: The new FX mini-series “Shogun” is getting a lot of credit simply for not being “Shogun,” the 1980 NBC mini-series also adapted from James Clavell’s best-selling novel about the last days of feudal Japan. But the new show stands and falls on the same terms as the old show: its success as an epic costumed soap opera. You can correct for wooden acting, dated production values and Eurocentrism, but you can’t really correct for the basic nature of the material.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: Sexism in Medicine? It’s Not ‘All in Her Head.’
description: A new book explores the history of discrimination in women’s health care and how it affects diagnosis and treatment today.
content: Six years ago, Dr. Elizabeth Comen, a breast cancer specialist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital in Manhattan, held the hand of a patient who was hours from death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Explosive Device Detonates Outside Alabama Attorney General’s Office
description: No one was injured in the explosion, which took place in downtown Montgomery one day after the state’s attorney general, Steve Marshall, said that he would not prosecute I.V.F. providers or families seeking the treatment.
content: An explosive device was detonated early Saturday outside the Alabama attorney general’s office in downtown Montgomery, Steve Marshall, the attorney general, said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Will Make Rare Visit to Southern Border on Same Day as Trump
description: The president, trying to go on the offensive over immigration, is planning to travel to Texas on Thursday, when Donald J. Trump is also set to visit a border city.
content: President Biden is planning to make a rare visit to the southern border on Thursday, his press secretary said, traveling to Brownsville, Texas, on the same day that former President Donald J. Trump has already scheduled a border trip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward and Hwaida Saad
title: Israel Launches Its Deepest Airstrikes in Lebanon in Years
description: At least two Hezbollah fighters were killed in strikes in the Bekaa Valley, and at least six other people were wounded, the mayor of a nearby city said.
content: Israeli airstrikes inside Lebanon on targets associated with the Hezbollah militia hit deeper than any in recent years on Monday, targeting an area close to the Syrian border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Hunt’ Review: The Hunter Becomes the Hunted
description: This modern-day fable, directed by Rupert Goold and starring Tobias Menzies, is styled with horror.
content: “Each town has its witch/Each parish its troll,” a character sings ominously while sharpening hedge shears. “We will with pleasure/Take the life from their veins.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing: Hungary Approved Sweden’s NATO Bid
description: Plus, movement in a possible Israel-Hamas deal.
content: After more than a year and a half of stalling, Hungary’s Parliament voted yesterday to approve Sweden as a new member of NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By OK McCausland
title: Girls to the Front: Olivia Rodrigo’s Fans Show Up in Force
description: At opening night of the pop star’s Guts World Tour, her devotees wore lavender and screamed their hearts out.
content: Olivia Rodrigo shot to pop stardom pretty much overnight: Her first single, “Drivers License,” rocketed to No. 1 in January 2021 while most of the world was still in coronavirus lockdown, making her the youngest artist to debut atop Billboard’s Hot 100 chart. In April of the following year, she finally brought her songs to life onstage with her punky Sour Tour, which played theaters, though she could have easily sold out arenas. Now she has done just that: Her tour supporting her second album, the cathartic, rock-oriented LP “Guts,” kicked off last Friday night at Acrisure Arena in Palm Desert, Calif., with a performance “advertising the power of girlhood,” The Times pop music critic Jon Caramanica wrote in his review. The venue, and its parking lot, was filled with young women ready to receive the message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanya Yanagihara
title: Why Artists Rule New York
description: It’s home to all types, but one group has made the city what it is today.
content: Unlike, say, Los Angeles or Washington, D.C. — one-industry towns where, more likely than not, you’re either in Hollywood or the government, or servicing them — New York has never been identified by a single business. Finance, theater, media, publishing: All live here, the worlds overlapping less than you’d imagine, given Manhattan’s limited space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: The Back Channel Talks to Secure McConnell’s Endorsement of Trump
description: The conversations between the Trump and McConnell camps have been happening between key advisers to both men.
content: Donald J. Trump and Mitch McConnell haven’t said a word to each other since December 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Lewis
title: China Is Running Out of Lines to Cross in the Taiwan Strait
description: A more robust approach is needed to deter Chinese military activities that could escalate into a war.
content: In 2020 the balance of military power in the Taiwan Strait began a gradual but profound shift in China’s favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Abbott Elementary’ Teaches Reading, Writing and Roll Camera
description: Each season of the ABC sitcom employs about 150 children. Its core curriculum: schooling Hollywood in what a show with child actors can be.
content: Willis Kwakye has attended the same school since 2021. He’s 13 now, an eighth grader, a veteran, someone who knows his way around the classrooms and the cafeteria. And sometimes, when he’s in his uniform with a math worksheet in front of him, “I can even think it’s real school for a little bit,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson
title: A Cyberattack on a UnitedHealth Unit Disrupts Prescription Drug Orders
description: For nearly a week, people have been waylaid at pharmacies after a unit of the nation’s largest insurer was shut down by a possible ransomware assault.
content: A cyberattack on a unit affiliated with UnitedHealthcare, the nation’s largest insurer, has disrupted drug prescription orders at thousands of pharmacies for nearly a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Co-Chair of Harvard Antisemitism Task Force Resigns
description: Professor Raffaella Sadun’s departure from the task force is a setback for a group set up to propose ways for Harvard to address antisemitism on campus.
content: The co-chair of a task force set up by Harvard University to combat antisemitism resigned on Sunday, the second high-profile resignation in the university’s efforts to address complaints that Jewish students have felt increasingly uncomfortable on campus since the Hamas attack of Oct. 7.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Andy Kim Sues to Block Preferential Treatment on Ballots in Senate Race
description: The federal lawsuit is seen as a direct challenge to Tammy Murphy, Mr. Kim’s chief rival in New Jersey, who stands to benefit most from the current ballot layout.
content: Representative Andy Kim, a Democrat running for Senate in New Jersey against the state’s first lady, filed a federal lawsuit on Monday that seeks to redesign the ballot before June’s contentious primary election, arguing the current layout unfairly benefits candidates supported by party leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: A Biden Ally Wades Into the Divide Over Gaza and Emerges With a Warning
description: After days of meetings with disaffected Democrats in Michigan, Representative Ro Khanna says President Biden cannot win the state without changes to his Middle East policy.
content: In the run-up to Michigan’s presidential primary on Tuesday, President Biden has stayed out of the state, where he is facing a campaign from liberal activists frustrated with his enduring support for Israel in the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Is in His Element
description: What can Joe Biden do about it?
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll get around to talking about Donald Trump’s big South Carolina primary win, but first I want to pick your brain about Joe Biden’s State of the Union address. It isn’t happening till next week, but I’m guessing the White House speechwriters are working hard on it now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Alberto Rodriguez and Carlos Nazario
title: Men’s Fashion With a Flair for the Dramatic
description: Scene-stealing silhouettes and oversize proportions step into the spotlight for spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Peter Anthony Morgan, Grammy-Winning Reggae Singer, Dies at 46
description: Known as “Peetah,” he and other children of the singer Denroy Morgan formed the group Morgan Heritage in the 1990s.
content: Peter Anthony Morgan, the lead singer of the reggae band Morgan Heritage, a Grammy Award-winning group that was formed by children of the singer Denroy Morgan and came to be known for its varied influences and tight vocal harmonies, died on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: What’s a ‘Girl Dinner’ Got to Do to Get Into the Dictionary These Days?
description: Why some words stick around long enough to get inducted — and what you can do to shoot your shot.
content: If you feel like you’re drowning in neologisms lately, you’re not delulu. The uptick in coinages has been noted by culture writers and TikTok users alike. There’s even a meme for slang overload, though it has been around since 2020. What feels significant about the latest boom is that dictionaries — once regarded merely as dusty tomes to be thrown down as a gauntlet by grammarians looking to defend the honor of their language — are the ones keeping track of it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Does It Mean to Dress Like an American?
description: A reader who is moving back to the United States from abroad wonders how to merge her personal wardrobe with that hard-to-define, American style of dress.
content: First of all, don’t fall prey to the jeans-and-leggings stereotype — or to any stars-’n’-stripes hogwash. It’s as hard to generalize about style across the United States as it is to generalize about style across Europe. New England is different from the South is different from Texas, which is different from California. (Even Northern and Southern California are different from each other.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Defending Academic Freedom on Campus
description: Readers discuss free speech on campus. Also: Mourning Flaco the owl; an Israel-Gaza cease-fire; facial recognition; domestic violence survivors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justices Seemed Open to Challenges to Social Media Laws
description: Also, Sweden’s NATO bid passed its final obstacle. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: During several hours of arguments today, the Supreme Court appeared skeptical of laws in Florida and Texas that ban major social media companies from making editorial judgments about which messages to allow. The justices seemed to align more closely with the social media companies, which accused the laws of violating the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Three Theories for Why Trump’s Primary Results Are Not Matching Expectations
description: He has underperformed the polls in each of the first three contests.
content: It’s still early in the primary season, but a whiff of a possible polling error is already in the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: How a Slow-Moving Court Became the Center of the World’s Hottest Debate
description: The International Court of Justice, the U.N.’s highest judicial body, is in the rare position of weighing in on a closely watched global conflict while hostilities are ongoing.
content: Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack on Israel had many unpredictable consequences, but the elevation of the International Court of Justice to global public attention is a particularly unexpected one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Jacob Rothschild, Banker Who Broke From His Fabled Family, Dies at 87
description: The fourth Baron Rothschild, he left the family banking dynasty to start his own company, becoming a powerful financier, patron of the arts and philanthropist.
content: Jacob Rothschild, a wealthy financier, patron of the arts and philanthropist with close ties to Israel, who broke with his family’s fabled banking dynasty at a time of radical change in the world of high finance, has died. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: The War in Gaza Turned This Longtime Michigan Democrat Against Biden
description: She knows the stakes. She loathes Donald Trump. But Terry Ahwal says she won’t back President Biden in November.
content: Tucked down in Terry Ahwal’s basement is her personal wall of fame: Here she is at the Obama White House Christmas party. Here is a framed thank-you note from President Bill Clinton. There she is grinning alongside Jennifer Granholm, the former governor of Michigan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By V.V. Ganeshananthan
title: Sold Into a Brothel at 15, a Japanese Girl Finds Strength in Words
description: “A Woman of Pleasure,” Kiyoko Murata’s first novel to be translated into English, explores the world of sex work in early-20th-century Japan.
content: When Aoi Ichi learns that her father is coming to visit, she is delighted. The young woman — a child, really — hasn’t seen him since the previous year, when she left their village on the southern Japanese island of Iojima for a mansion in the city of Kumamoto. “There are lots of men/but only one I love/my one and only pa,” she writes in her journal. She buys gifts for him to take to her mother and older sister and sweeps the street in front of her workplace with gusto. But he comes and goes without seeing her, “afraid to look his daughter in the eye.” He’s there only to sign a new promissory note with her employer borrowing more money against her labor, which is sex work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $800,000 Homes in California
description: A recently renovated house in Yucca Valley, a three-bedroom home in Benicia and a one-bedroom condominium in Laguna Niguel.
content: This house is in Flamingo Heights, a desert enclave about 20 minutes from Joshua Tree National Park. It is less than five minutes from La Copine, a popular restaurant housed in an old diner, and from Giant Rock Meeting Room, which offers pizza and drinks along with live music and other events. The Integratron, a large wooden dome built in 1954 “for the purpose of rejuvenation and time travel,” according to its website, is 10 minutes away. For those with more mundane needs, a Vons supermarket is within a 15-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Flaco’s Death Calls Attention to Bird Strikes and How to Prevent Them
description: The Eurasian eagle-owl was one of an estimated billion birds that will die in the United States this year after crashing into buildings.
content: Memorials sprang up in New York City over the weekend in honor of Flaco, a Eurasian eagle-owl who died on Friday after apparently striking a building on the Upper West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: As the Election Comes Into Focus, Pressure Builds in the West Wing
description: The presidency has always been a pressure cooker, but some in the Biden administration see wars, age, family stress and another race against Donald J. Trump combining with unusual force.
content: A former adviser to President Biden has compared life in the White House to dog years: Every day feels like a week, every year like seven. And then there are times like these when it can feel as though an entire term plays out every few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Wary of State Laws Regulating Social Media Platforms
description: The tech industry argues that laws in Florida and Texas, prompted by conservative complaints about censorship, violate the First Amendment. The court’s decision could fundamentally alter the nature of speech on the internet.
content: The Supreme Court seemed skeptical on Monday of laws in Florida and Texas that bar major social media companies from making editorial judgments about which messages to allow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Should You Consider Buying Your Childhood Home?
description: It might be a sensitive subject to bring up, but a path to homeownership for adult children could also make financial sense for their parents.
content: The stairs creaked in Jen Gorgano’s childhood home. Recalling those sounds makes Ms. Gorgano smile. “Growing up, we would always know who was running up and down the steps by how loud it was,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Safina
title: Like Many a Hero, Flaco the Owl Made His Choice
description: Flaco’s short life showed that freedom bundled with danger is worth the risk that it may be short and might end badly.
content: Flaco the owl is gone, but his life had all the elements of a classic hero’s story, not soon forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: John Patrick Shanley Reflects on His Accidental Retrospective
description: The playwright discusses the Broadway revival of “Doubt” and his latest, “Brooklyn Laundry.” “People are disagreeing violently with themselves,” he says.
content: In a life of feeling things incredibly deeply, John Patrick Shanley has experienced some thrilling highs: the rapturous audience response in 1984 to “Danny and the Deep Blue Sea,” his first success as a playwright; accepting an Academy Award in 1988 for best screenplay for “Moonstruck.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Herstik and Glenn Thrush
title: Ex-F.B.I. Informant to Be Held in Custody Indefinitely, Judge Says
description: Alexander Smirnov, the former informant, pleaded not guilty to charges that he lied to the F.B.I. about President Biden and his son Hunter accepting bribes.
content: Alexander Smirnov, the former F.B.I. informant charged with falsely claiming that President Biden and his son Hunter had accepted bribes, will be held in custody indefinitely because he poses a significant flight risk, a judge in California ruled on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Well Do You Know Berlin and Its Literary Landmarks?
description: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of this European capital with a turbulent history — and suggests six Berlin-based novels for your reading list.
content: This quick quiz tests your general knowledge of this European capital with a turbulent history — and suggests six Berlin-based novels for your reading list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Allison McCann, Sarah Almukhtar, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Robert Gebeloff and Denise Lu
title: No Box to Check: When the Census Doesn’t Reflect You
description: Most people of Middle Eastern and North African descent are classified as “white” in U.S. census data. Thousands of respondents to a Times survey told us how they actually identify.
content: Most people of Middle Eastern and North African descent are classified as “white” in U.S. census data. Thousands of respondents to a Times survey told us how they actually identify.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 4.9-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Idaho
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Associated Press
title: Jordan Airdrops Humanitarian Aid in Gaza
description: Jordanian planes dropped food and medical supplies with parachutes in central and southern Gaza. People were seen rowing boats to collect aid dropped into the sea.
content: Jordanian planes dropped food and medical supplies with parachutes in central and southern Gaza. People were seen rowing boats to collect aid dropped into the sea.
source.name: The New York Times
